byline.original: By NEIL AMDUR Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Bolivia's second national election in a year was a good deal more convincing than the first. The balloting last July was marked by widespread fraud, leading first to an annulment of the result and then to two military coups.
docs.lead_paragraph: Bolivia's second national election in a year was a good deal more convincing than the first. The balloting last July was marked by widespread fraud, leading first to an annulment of the result and then to two military coups.
docs.abstract: editorial holds elections are freest in very long time and should produce Bolivia's first popularly elected president in decade; adds recent US policies deserve some credit for democratic trends in Andes

headline.main: U.S. Moves in Nicaragua Rebellion Worrying Paraguay's Dictatorship; 'Process of Subversion' U.S. Moves in Nicaragua Rebellion Worrying Paraguay's Dictatorship 'Old Guard Is the Same' U.S. Military Aid Suspended 'Incompetence and Corruption'

byline.original: By JUAN de ONIS Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LIMA, Peru, July 19--Most Latin American governments are concerned that the fall of the Somoza regime in Nicaragua could lead to "another Cuba" in the region, but those governments committed to constitutional democracy are prepared to play an active...
docs.lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru, July 19--Most Latin American governments are concerned that the fall of the Somoza regime in Nicaragua could lead to "another Cuba" in the region, but those governments committed to constitutional democracy are prepared to play an active role to prevent this from happening.
docs.abstract: democratic group of Latin American nations formed by Costa Rica, Mexico and Andean group is seeking to block 'another Cuba' in Nicaragua; governments are prepared to play active role to prevent such a situation from developing (M)

headline.main: Democratic Latin Countries Seek To Block '2d Cuba' in Nicaragua; Venezuelans Favor Continued Role

byline.original: By JUAN de ONIS Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 20 (AP)--The cost of living in Uruguay rose 4.2 percent in June and 32.5 percent in the first half of the year, the Government announced today. Food prices rose 5 percent in June, and clothing costs nearly 8 percent.
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 20 (AP)--The cost of living in Uruguay rose 4.2 percent in June and 32.5 percent in the first half of the year, the Government announced today. Food prices rose 5 percent in June, and clothing costs nearly 8 percent.

docs.snippet: The 49th International P.E.N. Congress ended last night in Rio de Janeiro after adopting resolutions accusing governments of mistreating writers in many South American countries.
docs.lead_paragraph: The 49th International P.E.N. Congress ended last night in Rio de Janeiro after adopting resolutions accusing governments of mistreating writers in many South American countries.
docs.abstract: 44th International PEN Congress ends in Rio de Janiero after adopting resolutions accusing governments of mistreating writers in many South American countries; elects Per wastberg international president; congress unanimously approves resolution asking Soviet authorities to free Russian philosopher Igor Ogourtsov; asks South Korean Government to release Kim Chi Ha and Yang Sung Woo, dissidents who have been adopted as members of Japan PEN Club; Karen Kennedy, executive secretary of PEN American Center in NYC, says congress has stressed human rights and other problems in Latin America because it is being held in Latin American country (S)

headline.main: P.E.N. Ends Congress With Protest to Latins Over Abuse of Writers

docs.snippet: QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 10 Jaime Roldos Aguilera took office today as the first elected Ecuadorean President of this decade and pledged himself to the propagation of democracy and human rights throughout the hemisphere.
